author: Bloomberg.com
title: Chinese Equities Fluctuate Before Preliminary Factory Figures
text:
China’s stocks swung between gains and losses before the release of a preliminary manufacturing gauge.
The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.1 percent to 4,118.70 at 9:35 a.m. local time, paring its weekly gain to 4.1 percent. The Caixin-Markit China manufacturing PMI may rise to 49.7 this month from 49.4 in June, according to the median estimate of 16 economists.
The Shanghai index has rebounded 18 percent after a rout wiped out $4 trillion as the authorities undertook unprecedented measures to shore up equities. The response was criticized by Gao Xiqing, an architect of China’s stock market and a former top regulator,who said policy makers helped inflate equity prices and then mishandled the intervention.
The median trailing price-to-earnings ratio on mainland bourses is 73, higher than in any of the world’s 10 largest markets. It was 68 at the peak of China’s equity bubble in 2007, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Margin traders increased holdings of shares purchased with borrowed money for a fifth day on Thursday, with the outstanding balance of margin debt on the Shanghai Stock Exchange rising by 1.3 percent to 941.4 billion yuan ($151.6 billion).
